author: By Damien Cave and Matthew Abbott
title: Australia’s Witnesses to Fire’s Fury Are Desperate to Avoid a Sequel
description: Eight months after blazes devastated a wide swath of Australia, the most battered communities are trying to burn their way to safety as another fire season approaches.
content: MERINGO, Australia — On the mountainous South Coast of Australia, spring has begun — which means there are only a few more weeks to prepare for another fire season, looming in the distance like a villain on the march.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Over Headphones and in a Truck, the Philharmonic Stays Alive
description: With indoor performances still far-off, the orchestra has organized a “Soundwalk” in Central Park and outdoor pop-up concerts.
content: A steep set of stairs off a sidewalk plaza at Central Park West and 106th Street leads up to the Great Hill, an expansive patch of grass surrounded by thick woods and winding paths. I live nearby and go there often, especially during these largely homebound days. In truth, only in Manhattan could such a modest hill pass for “great.” Yet those 77 steps offer a dramatic entrance to a secluded space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Independent films face a challenge getting attention as festivals go virtual.
description: The loss of traditional film festivals because of the pandemic means more than missing out on cocktail parties and the red carpet.
content: The loss of traditional film festivals because of the pandemic means more than missing out on cocktail parties and the red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: West End Shows Announce a Return, Even as U.K. Coronavirus Cases Rise
description: “Six,” the hit musical, will start an 11-week run in November, with other shows including “The Mousetrap” also slated to resume soon.
content: LONDON — “Six,” the hit show about the ill-fated wives of King Henry VIII, is set to become the first musical to reopen on London’s West End since Britain went into lockdown in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Manley
title: How to Deal With Longing for a Distant Home
description: Where is home, really?
content: After months of containment, we understand a little better what it might be like to live on the moon. We have masked up to venture out the front door, floating in wide arcs around masked neighbors, while those unable to leave their homes have peered out the window at a world in orbit. For a period during the coronavirus pandemic, everyone on Earth has experienced the extremes of distance usually reserved for those in the death zone or outer space. In our rooms, apart, we have felt a longing for the places we can’t go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: How China Brought Almost 200 Million Students Back
description: We’re also rounding up thought-provoking ideas about Covid-era education, and bringing you the latest local updates for K-12 and college.
content: As countries struggle to safely reopen schools, China is harnessing the power of its authoritarian system to offer in-person learning for its vast population of students — including 195 million students in kindergarten through 12th grade at public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Zaretsky
title: Faces in a Nursing Home
description: As I helped feed these residents, I understood how our common humanity makes us ‘infinitely responsible’ to others.
content: HOUSTON — Twenty-five years ago, the philosopher Emmanuel Levinas died in Paris. Born in Lithuania and naturalized in France, Levinas had led weekly Torah readings until shortly before his death just shy of his 90th birthday. I often thought about his age this spring as I worked as a volunteer in a nursing home. Not only was Levinas as old as several of the residents who I helped to feed, but he was engaged in an activity — being with others — denied to the residents since the pandemic burst into their lives. In both his person and his principles, Levinas offers a guide for the crises that now threaten nursing homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Belarus Protests, Migrants, U.K. Coronavirus: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cookbook Celebrates 19th Amendment
description: The free digital cookbook from the American Bar Association features recipes from judges and lawyers.
content: To celebrate 100 years since the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote, the American Bar Association Commission on the Nineteenth Amendment has assembled a digital cookbook, with recipes from judges, Supreme Court Justices, lawyers, scholars and others connected to the legal field. The introduction notes that suffragists published several cookbooks in their day, so there’s a tradition. The contributors include Janet Napolitano, Merrick Garland, Nina Totenberg, Amal Clooney, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and her daughter, Jane Ginsburg. Hillary Rodham Clinton offers chocolate chip cookies. Neil Gorsuch’s lively recipe for a warming Colorado green chile stew suggests that he knows his way around the kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Trapped by Pandemic, Ships’ Crews Are Buckling
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 14, 2020.
content: “Ports and countries want the cargo, but when it comes to the crew who are bringing the cargo to them, they are not helping us.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Parents vs. Nonparents in the Workplace
description: Workers with children bristle at the notion that they are enjoying special privileges.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside Trump’s Immigration Crackdown
description: Two filmmakers were granted rare access to Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations. The Trump administration is now seeking to block the release of their documentary.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Jack (‘Murph the Surf’) Murphy, Heist Mastermind, Dies at 83
description: He stole the Star of India and other gems from the Museum of Natural History. Two days later he was under arrest.
content: He called himself “Murph the Surf,” a tanned, roguish, party-loving beach boy from Miami, and he transfixed the nation in 1964 by pulling off the biggest jewel heist in New York City history — the celebrated snatching of the Star of India, a sapphire larger than a golf ball, and a haul of other gems from the American Museum of Natural History.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron
title: The Eerie Silence of an N.F.L. Stadium Makes the Game Even More for TV
description: The Superdome in New Orleans had a dystopian feel as football returned without one of its most loyal congregations. Oh, and Tom Brady flopped as the Saints beat the Buccaneers, 34-23.
content: NEW ORLEANS — The ritual of Saints football went on almost as normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: National Museum of African American History and Culture Is Reopening
description: While it won’t yet have an exhibition on recent protests against racism and police violence, its founding director acknowledges that it is reopening against the backdrop of “a changed America.”
content: The National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington will reopen to the public on Friday — one of four Smithsonian Institution museums that are involved in the latest phase of reopening, the Smithsonian announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Turmeric May Ease Knee Arthritis
description: A curcumin extract eased pain, stiffness and physical function in those with osteoarthritis of the knee.
content: Turmeric — the main spice in curry — may help ease the pain and stiffness of knee osteoarthritis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: A Building Courtyard Becomes a Wedding Venue
description: The pandemic didn’t stop these high school sweethearts from marrying. It just downsized their party.
content: In early March, Gabriela Vieira and Matthew Hargraves moved into a new one-bedroom apartment in Midwood, Brooklyn. The couple, both 25, had spent the last few years in an older building in Gravesend. They were planning a big July wedding and were looking forward to upgrading to something a little more luxurious for the next chapter of their lives together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tamryn Spruill
title: A’ja Wilson for M.V.P., and More W.N.B.A. Awards Picks
description: Wilson, the Aces’ All-Star forward, isn’t the only one from Las Vegas deserving of honors this year.
content: Talent in the W.N.B.A. runs so deep that many teams have bench players who would start on other teams. With some of the league’s most familiar faces sitting out or having received medical exemptions for this season because of the coronavirus pandemic, under-the-radar players have seized their increased minutes as opportunities to shine. And while lesser-known players were compiling breakout seasons, some established stars were helping their teams win in unexpected ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden’s Legal Preparations
description: The former vice president prepares for a voting battle: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: With court battles playing out over voting, Biden assembles a legal crisis-response team. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Experts are urging drug companies to be more transparent about how they’re testing vaccines.
content: A growing number of independent scientists and public health officials are urging drug companies to be more transparent about how they’re running the clinical trials for their vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Biden’s Vulnerability
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: The latest New York Times/Siena College poll showed Joe Biden to be leading President Trump in four important swing states. But it also showed how Biden could lose the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia and Edward Wong
title: War Crimes Risk Grows for U.S. Over Saudi Strikes in Yemen
description: State Department officials have raised alarms about the legal risk in aiding airstrikes that kill civilians. The Trump administration recently suppressed findings as it sold more weapons to Gulf nations.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump hosts the signing of a diplomatic agreement between Israel and the United Arab Emirates on Tuesday, the White House ceremony will also serve as tacit recognition of Mr. Trump’s embrace of arms sales as a cornerstone of his foreign policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: On the Eve of New York Fashion Week, What’s Next?
description: Four fashion insiders debate the questions swirling around shows, clothes and race.
content: Last season, the rising tide of Covid-19 lapped at fashion’s heels as the style set moved from city to city, show to show. In New York, Chinese designers, stuck at home, missed their collection bow; as Milan began, one Italian had died of the virus. By the end of that week, Armani had decided to hold a show with no audience. In Paris, parties were canceled, masks handed out and ushers stood tall with big vats of hand sanitizer. Then, just after everyone scattered for home, the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. Restricts Chinese Apparel and Tech Products, Citing Forced Labor
description: The new restrictions, announced Monday, fall short of a broader ban on cotton and tomatoes from Xinjiang that the administration was poised to announce last week.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday announced new restrictions on imports of apparel, hair products and technology goods from certain Chinese companies, saying those entities had used forced labor in the Xinjiang region to make their products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Vasilis Dimitriou, Keeper of a Fading Movie Art, Dies at 84
description: He was one of Europe’s last Hollywood billboard painters, creating, by hand, giant film promotions for theaters since the end of World War II.
content: ATHENS — Vasilis Dimitriou, an artist who sought to keep the venerable art of the painted Hollywood billboard from fading away, creating more than 8,000 works for Greek theaters that virtually chronicled the history of movies since World War II, died on Sept. 6 in Athens. He was 84 and one of the last surviving movie billboard painters in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The Intercept Promised to Reveal Everything. Then Its Own Scandal Hit.
description: Internal documents show how a source ended up in jail — and the fallout in the newsroom.
content: Where were you when you first heard about the Snowden leak?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: School Closures Cut a Critical Line to Dental Care for Poor Students
description: Programs that allowed hygienists to visit schools to look for cavities and tooth decay have been suspended because of the pandemic. Students from low-income families may be hit the hardest.
content: Before the pandemic, it was not unusual for Tiffany Foy and a team of other dental hygienists to visit schools in rural and urban parts of Oregon to treat the teeth of thousands of children in a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: When Will the Air Quality Get Better?
description: Monday: The advice is to take it hour by hour. Also: President Trump is set to visit California, where he’ll confront a reality he’s denied.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Pipeline Politics: Why Nord Stream 2 Is Back in the Spotlight
description: The attack on the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny has revived calls to cancel a gas pipeline from Russia to Germany. Here’s what lies behind the debate.
content: MOSCOW — The poisoning of the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny has revived a long-simmering feud over a nearly completed Russian natural-gas pipeline to Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Sept. 14, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 14, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 14, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and David M. Halbfinger
title: A White House Ceremony Will Celebrate a Diplomatic Win and Campaign Gift
description: The leaders of Israel, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have a stake in President Trump’s re-election and helped him become a peacemaker.
content: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has long owed a debt to President Trump, who has repeatedly bestowed diplomatic gifts at crucial moments as Mr. Netanyahu has battled for his political survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: After Winning Wild U.S. Open, Dominic Thiem Heads to Clay
description: Thiem said his next tournament will be the French Open, on the surface where he is most comfortable.
content: Back in Europe, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic only watched the first four sets of the United States Open men’s final before heading to bed after midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: In Berlin, the Art World Spreads Out to Stay Safe
description: The first major international art event since the lockdown started took place at smaller venues around the city, rather than under a single roof.
content: BERLIN — It has been a long time coming, but after six months of coronavirus-enforced inactivity, the international art world was re-energized by a hectic week here of live exhibitions and events. With all the summer’s most important live art fairs, exhibitions and auctions canceled, Berlin Art Week, which ended Sunday, became the art world’s first significant international event since March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: As N.Y.C. Reopens Schools, Homeless Families Face New Challenges
description: As a new experiment in remote learning begins, students who live in shelters or doubled up with family may not have the resources they need.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Today Is for Nachos
description: Find comfort in the easy favorite.
content: Good morning. How are you? You getting enough sleep, or sleeping all the time? You eating enough, not enough, too much? How’s your stress level? You feeling optimistic? Or the opposite? I watched the sun rise the other morning and asked myself those questions. I found I could not answer them. And I can’t be alone in that. We’re caught in the continuum between what was and what will be, and it’s dizzying. We’re all in, all the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Los Angeles Winemaker Heads in a New Direction
description: The vintner Mark Blatty has experimented with a white wine blend, Aurora, after focusing on reds.
content: Aurora, a blend of sauvignon blanc, sémillon and viognier, is the latest wine from Byron Blatty in Los Angeles. It’s the first white made by the winery, founded in 2014 by Mark Blatty, a native Angeleno who worked in television, and his wife, Jenny. Aurora is a rich, citric blend that announces its oak and should be nothing short of delicious in a couple of years. Mark Blatty concentrates on reds, like the other winemakers in Los Angeles County, a wine region undergoing a revival. (It had been the cradle of the state’s winemaking, dating back to Spanish monasteries like Mission San Gabriel.) “It’s a hot climate so red wines do better,” he said. “Besides, they’re our first love.” Grapes like syrah, Grenache and cabernet sauvignon go into big, expensive New World-style wines that have enough acidity to give them backbone and luxurious depth while keeping sweetness in check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: These Families Feel Forgotten as N.Y.C. Pushes to Open Schools
description: Months of remote learning have taken a harsh toll on New York City’s roughly 114,000 homeless students and their families.
content: This past March was a blur for Arianne Allan, a mother of two who lives in a Brooklyn homeless shelter. She spent the entire month battling the coronavirus in her small shelter unit. It was impossible to maintain distance from her son and daughter, and they both got sick, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Steven Cohen Agrees to Buy the Mets, Again
description: Cohen, a billionaire hedge fund investor from Long Island, pulled out of a deal to buy the team in January but emerged victorious in a new bidding process this summer.
content: Frustrated Mets fans have for years pined for a new owner to swoop in and buy their team, someone to save it from what they felt was decades of mismanagement and mediocrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: With Tensions High, Trump’s Ambassador to China Is Stepping Down
description: Terry Branstad, a former Republican governor of Iowa and early supporter of Mr. Trump’s candidacy, will leave his post as the top American diplomat in China.
content: The American ambassador to China, Terry Branstad, announced on Monday that he would step down in early October after a tenure that paralleled a sharp deterioration in relations between China and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Let’s Fret the Night Together
description: The Biden campaign and the world it’s playing out in are making us all nervous wrecks.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I am generally a pretty cheerful person. But I have to say that the news has been really, really depressing lately. At least on the domestic front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Progressive Donor Susan Sandler to Give $200 Million to Racial Justice Groups
description: Her efforts will support organizations trying to build political power in states that are undergoing rapid demographic change.
content: Susan Sandler, a liberal philanthropist, has announced a $200 million investment in racial justice organizations, targeting areas across the South and the Southwest that are experiencing rapid demographic transformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Henry, Jackie James, Rey Jarrell and Amelie Zilber
title: Why You Should Care About TikTok
description: Forcing a sale of the app is a show of power, but it doesn’t really protect your privacy.
content: Maybe you first learned about TikTok when your kids tried to teach you the Toosie Slide, or when you came across a kinetic Charli D’Amelio video that got millions of likes. Or was it when your nephew started a small fire because of the “outlet challenge?” In any case, you’ve definitely heard that President Trump was intent on banning it and forced it to make a deal with an American company. But who really cares about an app — used mostly by Gen Z?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Trump Health Aide Pushes Bizarre Conspiracies and Warns of Armed Revolt
description: Michael R. Caputo told a Facebook audience without evidence that left-wing hit squads were being trained for insurrection and accused C.D.C. scientists of “sedition.”
content: WASHINGTON — The top communications official at the powerful cabinet department in charge of combating the coronavirus made outlandish and false accusations on Sunday that career government scientists were engaging in “sedition” in their handling of the pandemic and that left-wing hit squads were preparing for armed insurrection after the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe, Ana Swanson and Erin Griffith
title: TikTok’s Proposed Deal Seeks to Mollify U.S. and China
description: The Chinese-owned app designed a compromise to satisfy U.S. security concerns. The terms are now under review by the Trump administration.
content: WASHINGTON — After more than six weeks, two White House executive orders, new Chinese regulations and multiple bidders, a deal for the social media app TikTok has boiled down to one main strategy: mitigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Foden
title: Vivid Street Scenes From Salvador, Brazil
description: After living for nearly half a decade in the capital city of the Brazilian state of Bahia, a photographer offers an intimate look at a city where the act of celebration is indelibly ingrained.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Stephanie Foden shares a collection of images from Brazilian state of Bahia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Delicious Escape to France
description: A new film looks at a working holiday in France taken by the chef David Kinch and his Manresa kitchen team.
content: For the 15th anniversary of Manresa, his restaurant in Los Gatos, Calif., David Kinch took his entire kitchen team to France where they shared the cooking, including their own California style, in three notable kitchens alongside the French masters: Alain Solivérès at Le Taillevent in Paris, Gérald Passedat at Le Petit Nice in Marseille, and Glenn Viel and Jean-André Charial at L’Oustau de Baumanière in Les Baux-de-Provence. A 90-minute film, “A Chef’s Voyage,” recorded it all. It’s a feast, not just for the food shown in exquisite detail, but for the images of the countryside, the shore, and the streets and markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: 400,000 Immigrants Can Be Forced to Leave the U.S., Court Rules
description: People from countries like El Salvador and Haiti who won temporary protected status after fleeing natural disaster and war can be forced to return home, a federal appeals court ruled.
content: LOS ANGELES — A federal appeals court ruled on Monday that the Trump administration acted within its authority in terminating legal protections that have allowed hundreds of thousands of immigrants to live and work legally in the United States, sometimes for decades, after fleeing conflict or natural disasters in their home countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: What Happened at New York’s First Pandemic Fashion Show?
description: Jason Wu tests out the runway’s new normal.
content: Jason Wu said he was feeling Zen, swiveling in an office chair in his studio near Penn Station.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Parties Delay the Start of In-Person Classes at Some U.S. High Schools
description: A federal judge ruled that pandemic safety restrictions in Pennsylvania were unconstitutional. The damage to the world’s major economies from the virus has been six times more severe than the 2009 financial crisis.
content: Several K-12 school districts in the U.S. Northeast have delayed the start of in-person classes in recent days after high school students attended large parties, leading to concern about increased spread of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Brazenly ignoring restrictions, Trump held a big indoor rally in Nevada.
description: At a rally in a Las Vegas suburb Sunday night, President Trump delivered his counterfactual stump speech, making wildly inaccurate claims about the trend lines of the coronavirus and about his Democratic rival, Joseph R. Biden, Jr., whom he said was waging a “dangerous war on the police” and was also “too weak to be president.”
content: At a rally in a Las Vegas suburb Sunday night, President Trump delivered his counterfactual stump speech, making wildly inaccurate claims about the trend lines of the coronavirus and about his Democratic rival, Joseph R. Biden, Jr., whom he said was waging a “dangerous war on the police” and was also “too weak to be president.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Djokovic, After U.S. Open, Says He Is Working on the Mental Side of Tennis
description: In his first news conference since being disqualified from the Open, Djokovic said he hoped to be a “wiser” player.
content: Eight days after his abrupt disqualification from the United States Open for accidentally hitting a line judge with a ball, Novak Djokovic said that he saw the incident as an opportunity to improve the mental side of his game and that he hoped he could be a “wiser” player as a result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israeli Settler Gets 3 Life Sentences for Firebomb Attack on Family
description: The shocking killing of a young couple and their son in a West Bank village drew condemnation from Palestinians and Israeli leaders.
content: LOD, Israel — An Israeli settler was sentenced Monday to three life terms in prison plus 20 years for killing a Palestinian couple and their young son in a firebomb attack on their home in July 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Saporito
title: Don’t Let the Pandemic End a 100-Year-Old Soccer Legacy
description: My league played through World War II and 9/11. Why do we have to stop now?
content: Soccer was once the sport of immigrants in a city of immigrants. Now, it’s everyone’s game. The Cosmopolitan Soccer League, one of the oldest continually operating soccer leagues in the country, began life as the German-American Soccer League in 1923. Some of those teams are still around, joined by more than 100 others of all varieties, such as Astoria United, Manhattan Kickers Football Club, Greek-American Atlas Astoria, Williamsburg International and N.Y.P.D. Finest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: A Second Paris Deputy Mayor Resigns Amid Sexual Abuse Allegations
description: For the second time in weeks, prosecutors opened an investigation into claims against a former deputy mayor, one in a series of sexual harassment and assault scandals that have rocked France recently.
content: PARIS — A deputy mayor of Paris resigned on Monday and prosecutors opened an investigation of him for possible sexual assault, just weeks after they started an investigation into rape allegations against a former deputy mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Gordinier
title: In Jorie Graham’s Poetry, the End of Days and the Pleasures of the Flow
description: “Runaway,” Graham’s 15th collection, considers the apocalypse, beautifully.
content: RUNAWAY New PoemsBy Jorie Graham
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: 3 Takeaways From the New York Times/Siena College Poll
description: President Trump and Joe Biden can both point to advantages in our new poll of Minnesota, Nevada, New Hampshire and Wisconsin.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: A Poet of Multitudes, Whose Work Feels Newly Pertinent
description: The lesson we find in Walt Whitman is a reminder of the complexity of the individual, and how we can find succor in art even when its maker is deeply imperfect.
content: There are some artists who seem to have an uncanny ability to predict turns in the culture: Think of Judy Chicago in the ’70s, with her unclassifiable multimedia works that redefined what spaces women were able to occupy, or Andy Warhol, whose deadpan films and silk-screens — flat works, in fact and affect — predated memes, the hydra of art and commercialism and a consumption with fame. They are Cassandras, these artists, possessed of a weird and spooky gift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden Creates Legal War Room, Preparing for a Big Fight Over Voting
description: With two former solicitors general and hundreds of lawyers, the Biden campaign is bracing for an extended legal battle and hoping to maintain trust in the electoral process.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign is establishing a major new legal operation, bringing in two former solicitors general and hundreds of lawyers in what the campaign billed as the largest election protection program in presidential campaign history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
title: Party Insiders Put Yoshihide Suga on Brink of Being Japan’s Prime Minister
description: In an emergency vote restricted to members of Parliament and select delegates, the governing party overwhelmingly backed the leading symbol of continuity from Shinzo Abe’s premiership.
content: TOKYO — Japan’s governing party on Monday anointed Yoshihide Suga, the current chief cabinet secretary, as its choice for the next prime minister, settling on what it saw as a safe pair of hands to grapple with the country’s many economic and strategic challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Walt Whitman, Poet of a Contradictory America
description: During the Civil War era, the writer emerged as an emblem of the country’s dissonance. Now, in the midst of another all-consuming national crisis, his work feels uncannily relevant.
content: SIX DAYS AFTER the first cannonades of the Civil War boomed out at Fort Sumter, S.C., Walt Whitman, the great ennobler of the American soul, made a resolution: to go on a diet. He scribbled the plan in his notebook. “By ignoring all drinks but water and pure milk” — and by avoiding fatty meats and late suppers as well — he would “inaugurate” for himself a “great body,” a “purged, cleansed, spiritualized, invigorated body.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Climate Change, Wildfires, Life on Venus: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: A Rare Middle East Triumph
description: And — yes — a triumph for Trump, too.
content: For years, the Trump administration’s peacemaking efforts in the Middle East have been the object of relentless derision in elite foreign-policy circles, some of it justified. Yet with Friday’s announcement that Bahrain would join the United Arab Emirates as the second Arab state in 30 days to normalize ties with Israel, the administration has done more for regional peace than most of its predecessors, including an Obama administration that tried hard and failed badly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson and Edgar Sandoval
title: Rochester Mayor Abruptly Fires Police Chief Over Daniel Prude’s Death
description: The mayor removed the police chief two weeks before his retirement date, and said the city had not taken Mr. Prude’s death seriously.
content: The mayor of Rochester, N.Y., a city reeling since the disclosure that a Black man died after officers placed him in a hood, lashed out at the Police Department on Monday, saying that it “views everything through the eyes of the badge,” and calling for a federal civil rights investigation into the man’s death and other arrests going back three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: This U.S. Open Will Be Judged by the Future of Osaka and Thiem
description: Does this Grand Slam title deserve an asterisk given the absence of so many stars? Not if Dominic Thiem and Naomi Osaka endure at the top of the sport. They appear on track for just that.
content: Naomi Osaka and Dominic Thiem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Nvidia Buys Arm From SoftBank for $40 Billion
description: The move gives Nvidia a way into mobile chips, but the acquisition is likely to face regulatory scrutiny.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Nvidia said on Sunday that it would acquire the British chip designer Arm from SoftBank in deal worth about $40 billion, a move that could reshape the battle over technology that powers smartphones and data centers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Messner
title: An Unflinching Child’s-Eye View of Sexual Abuse
description: The 10-year-old narrator of Kimberly Brubaker Bradley’s “Fighting Words” eases her way into sharing the awful truth of what she and her sister survived.
content: FIGHTING WORDSBy Kimberly Brubaker Bradley
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is This How the TikTok Saga Ends?
description: An unexpected, late twist in the long-running drama over the sale of the Chinese video app.
content: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Stirone, Kenneth Chang and Dennis Overbye
title: Life on Venus? Astronomers See a Signal in Its Clouds
description: The detection of a gas in the planet’s atmosphere could turn scientists’ gaze to a planet long overlooked in the search for extraterrestrial life.
content: High in the toxic atmosphere of the planet Venus, astronomers on Earth have discovered signs of what might be life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wildfires Are Reaching Once Tranquil Places on the West Coast
description: Lake Madrone in California and Scio, Ore., are among some of the communities forced to deal with wildfires after long avoiding them. Unpredictable wind gusts may spread the flames.
content: Firefighting teams across the West Coast battled shifting winds and drier weather on Monday, sparking new fire fronts that threatened to make kindling out of forests as states struggled to tame flames that have burned more than five million acres this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Coral Davenport
title: As Trump visits a scorched California, he’ll confront a scientific reality he denies.
description: A president who has mocked climate change and pushed policies that accelerate it is set to be briefed on the scorched earth and ash-filled skies that experts say are the predictable result.
content: When President Trump flew to California on Monday to assess the state’s raging forest fires, he came face to face with the grim consequences of a reality he has stubbornly refused to accept: the devastating effects of a warming planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Independent Watchdog Report Finds Inequity in Farm Aid Payments
description: Big farms, along with Southern farmers, disproportionately benefited from the trade assistance program, according to the Government Accountability Office.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s multibillion dollar farm aid program, managed by Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue, has poured a disproportionate amount of money into big farms and southern states, including the secretary’s home state of Georgia, according to a report released Monday by the Government Accountability Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Do Masks Impede Children’s Development?
description: Scientists who have studied the ways children process and use the information hidden by masks say that children will find ways to communicate, and that parents and teachers can help.
content: Nothing about masks and masking has come easily in the United States, it seems. There were mixed and confusing messages back at the beginning of the pandemic, then political discussion that got in the way of sane public health decision-making, as well as circulating disinformation, anger, and a certain amount of shaming and finger-pointing, by those who wanted masks and by those who didn’t. But evidence keeps accumulating that masks help keep us all safer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: The Arctic Is Shifting to a New Climate Because of Global Warming
description: Open water and rain, rather than ice and snow, are becoming typical of the region, a new study has found.
content: The effects of global warming in the Arctic are so severe that the region is shifting to a different climate, one characterized less by ice and snow and more by open water and rain, scientists said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson Pushes to Backtrack on E.U. Deal, Despite Party Revolt
description: The British prime minister’s move to rewrite a treaty that settled Northern Ireland’s post-Brexit status raised fears that trade negotiations with the European Union could be impaired.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson survived a rebellion among lawmakers from his Conservative Party on Monday as the Parliament advanced Brexit legislation even after the government admitted that it would violate international law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Brasted and Rick Rojas
title: As Hurricane Sally Looms, the Gulf Coast Braces Itself Yet Again
description: Forecasters expect the storm to bring rain to Louisiana before making landfall in Mississippi with potentially lethal storm surge and powerful winds.
content: NEW ORLEANS — The Gulf Coast was bracing yet again on Monday for a barrage of storm surge and pounding rain as Hurricane Sally lurched toward the region less than a month after Hurricane Laura’s powerful winds pulverized a section of the coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Yoshihide Suga, TikTok, Venus: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Mr. Suga, the longtime chief cabinet secretary to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, swept an election for the leadership of the conservative Liberal Democratic Party — all but assuring that he will become prime minister after a vote in Parliament in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Wildfire Smoke Chokes Canada’s Western Skies
description: Residents retreated indoors after smoke from wildfires in the U.S. descended on Vancouver and other communities in British Columbia.
content: OTTAWA — Residents of Vancouver and other communities in British Columbia retreated indoors over the weekend as dense smoke from wildfires in the United States filled the skies, disrupting life in the Pacific Coast province.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: TikTok Was a Wasted Opportunity
description: The TikTok battle was a chance to debate big questions about technology and government. We missed it.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Fusilli Made for Chianti
description: There’s a new gluten-free pasta on the block: Fava beans power this fusilli from Explore Cuisine.
content: Joining the many gluten-free pastas made from vegetables is fava bean fusilli, from Explore Cuisine, a company that specializes in such alternatives. The little corkscrews have a mild flavor, but they’re softer and somewhat more fragile than traditional fusilli, so they’re best cooked al dente. Toss them with pesto or fresh chopped tomatoes and herbs, or diced butternut squash and mushrooms as the weather cools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Dominic Thiem Comes Back From Down 2 Sets to Win U.S. Open Final
description: Thiem stormed back to beat Alexander Zverev for the title in a fifth-set tiebreaker.
content: Grand Slam tennis is back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: South Dakota Investigates Fatal Crash Involving Attorney General
description: The attorney general, Jason Ravnsborg, called 911 to say he thought he had hit a deer late Saturday. The next morning, the body of Joe Boever, 55, was found nearby, the authorities said.
content: South Dakota’s attorney general, Jason Ravnsborg, was driving home alone from a Republican Party dinner on Saturday night when his car hit something, possibly a deer, he told the authorities. By the next day, the news had taken a grim turn: A man had been found dead near the highway. And the state’s top law enforcement officer was under investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Marino
title: A Late-Summer Tomato Sauce — and a Candle to Go With It
description: The skin-care line founders Matthew Malin and Andrew Goetz share their aromatic take on a classic recipe.
content: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: Tales of Brutality From ‘Twelve Angry Men … and Women’
description: This brilliantly designed performance, staged for a live audience in Brooklyn and filmed for YouTube, is an urgent response to police misconduct.
content: The instant the string quartet finished, the police car was there: red and blue lights flashing, siren screaming as it approached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.1 Million Homes in California
description: A Queen Anne Victorian in Berkeley, a ranch with horse facilities in Calabasas and a semidetached house a few blocks from the ocean in Newport Beach.
content: This house was built about a block south of its current address and moved in the early 1900s. The first owner, George C. Pape, was also the proprietor of the Berkeley Planing Mill, an association the Berkeley Architectural Heritage Association credits for the intricacy of the home’s exterior ornamentation. A previous owner began the restoration process continued by the sellers; in addition to updating the kitchen, bathrooms and HVAC systems, many of the original decorative details were restored or replicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Jerry Brown on a California Exodus: ‘Tell Me: Where Are You Going to Go?’
description: From his ranch, the former California governor is experiencing the same smoky air wafting through much of the state. “We are causing this,” he declared in an interview.
content: LOS ANGELES — Jerry Brown, the former governor of California, could barely make out the mountains in the distance from his ranch in the city of Williams on Sunday. Every few minutes, he picked up his phone to check the latest air quality reading. “Unhealthy,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Volkswagen Has Kept Promises to Reform, U.S. Overseer Says
description: A court-appointed monitor said in a final report that the carmaker has become more ethical following a devastating emissions cheating scandal, but ‘continued vigilance’ is needed.
content: Volkswagen completed the corporate equivalent of probation after a court-appointed monitor said Monday that the carmaker had fulfilled the conditions of a 2017 plea bargain stemming from its use of illegal software to evade emissions regulations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: ‘In Baseball, There Is Neither Crying Nor the Asterisk’
description: Fans can debate whether this season’s records count. But M.L.B.’s official historian insists this year’s achievements — including Alec Mills’s no-hitter on Sunday — are as real as any other.
content: Javier Baez was already celebrating when he fielded the ball. The shortstop for the Chicago Cubs gathered himself, threw to first, and gave Alec Mills the second no-hitter of this pandemic-shortened baseball season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: The Hidden History Baked Into a Cooking Pot
description: An experiment with unglazed clay pots hinted at how much archaeologists can learn about ancient cultures from cooking vessels.
content: Sure, astrophysicists have big telescopes, and oceanographers use underwater robots, but some researchers get to cook venison, lots of it, in the name of science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: Imagined as a Blockbuster in China, ‘Mulan’ Fizzles
description: Disney’s live-action remake had already drawn a global backlash. Chinese audiences mocked it for other reasons, including historical inaccuracies and stereotyping.
content: Disney had been pinning its hopes on its $200 million live-action remake of “Mulan” as a way to finally deliver a blockbuster that resonated culturally with moviegoers in China, the world’s No. 2 film market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Embattled Belarus Strongman Travels to Russia to Seek Help From Putin
description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko broke into a sweat after the Russian president suggested new elections.
content: MOSCOW — Besieged by protesters at home, the embattled strongman leader of Belarus, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, traveled to Russia on Monday seeking help from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Nxivm Had a Cult Leader Made for the Internet
description: In HBO’s “The Vow,” the self-help organization’s ringleader Keith Raniere has the unhinged charisma of an internet meme.
content: There is a scene early in “The Vow,” HBO’s documentary series on Nxivm, where an eager recruit meets the group’s mysterious leader for the first time. After being described in near-godlike terms by his acolytes in Albany — who rhapsodize about his supposed world-record I.Q., Judo mastery and concert-level piano skills — Keith Raniere finally emerges at an intimate gathering. He is revealed to be a squat man with a dweebish presentation. In a home video, he stalks artlessly around the room, flipping his feathered, center-parted hair and pecking everyone on the lips. “There was a part of me that was like, This is the dude?” said the recruit, a filmmaker named Mark Vicente, after leaving the organization. “But you never know where wisdom comes from. You know?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: For Prisoners in the West, the Virus and the Wildfires Are Colliding Threats
description: Prisoners are more vulnerable than ever to the twin crises of the pandemic and a historic wildfire season.
content: As wildfires tore through huge swaths of Oregon this week, prisoners were hurried away from the encroaching flames — not to freedom but to an overcrowded state prison, where they slept shoulder-to-shoulder in cots, and in some cases on the floor. Food was in short supply, showers and toilets few, and fights broke out between rival gang members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Building Public Places for a Covid World’
description: How would you reinvent a space in your area so that it both advances wellness and knits the community together? That’s a question The Times asked architects, and we’re posing it to students, too.
content: Featured Article: “Building Public Places for a Covid World” by James S. Russell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis
title: Pearls Are a Boy’s Best Friend
description: For men, the pearl necklace represents both the unraveling and buttressing of gender norms.
content: It was on the pink carpet of the 2019 Met Gala that Harry Styles helped reintroduce men to the mollusk. The English former boy-bander, an event co-chair, wore a vaguely Grecian look created for him by the Gucci creative director Alessandro Michele that included a sheer black blouse with a ruffle front and pussy bow, high high-waisted pants, patent-leather heeled boots and a single, perfect pearl earring that owed as much to the theme of the evening — camp — as it did to Rembrandt’s paintings of 17th-century Dutch noblemen (and, yes, Vermeer’s). Since then, Styles, 26, has graduated to wearing a string of pearls around his neck, which he has typically paired with boyish tops: a checkered Marni polo; a Lanvin cardigan featuring Babar the Elephant; an acid-green crew-neck sweater by Magda Archer in collaboration with Marc Jacobs, fellow pearl-necklace enthusiast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sourdoughs and Whole-Wheat Loaves, Oh My
description: These offerings from Eli’s Bread on the Upper East Side have found restaurant fans, too.
content: Giuseppe Bruno, who owns the restaurants Sistina and Caravaggio on the Upper East Side, wanted breads for his restaurants fresher than most and made with high-quality traditional and ancient grains. His search led to Eli Zabar and his company Eli’s Bread, which has adapted some of its breads, baked in the afternoon, to Mr. Bruno’s specifications. There’s a hefty, round version of Mr. Zabar’s rich whole-wheat health loaf and a sourdough oval with a moist, tender crumb that Mr. Zabar has made larger for Mr. Bruno. It’s called Jerusalem loaf because at one time it was baked at a kosher bakery. Mr. Bruno serves the breads with olive oil and a compound butter and says that now the customers who used to refuse bread do not turn these down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francine Prose
title: What if We Pursued Vigilante Justice on Reality TV?
description: In “Payback,” the veteran novelist Mary Gordon gives score-settling a modern twist.
content: PAYBACK By Mary Gordon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 1 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Cam Newton looked terrific, Tom Brady looked fairly terrible, and there were upsets all over the place in a wild slate of games.
content: It was a week of superstars showing off new uniforms, many players choosing to stay in the locker room for the national anthem, teams playing through horrible air conditions out west, and stadiums being mostly empty because of coronavirus precautions. But a few shocking upsets provided a thrilling Sunday, reminding everyone that football games can go sideways quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: This ‘Lovecraft Country’ Actor Is Happy in Her Own Skin
description: Wunmi Mosaku, who plays Ruby in the HBO horror thriller, discusses Sunday’s extraordinary episode: “The worst thing was the shape-shifting.”
content: This interview contains spoilers for Sunday’s episode of “Lovecraft Country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Annie Karni
title: Trump Defies Nevada Directive as Thousands Gather for Indoor Rally
description: The president unloaded his regular, inaccurate onslaught against Joseph R. Biden Jr., and there were no signs of any attempts at social distancing at the event.
content: HENDERSON, Nev. — Thousands of Trump supporters, the vast majority of them forgoing face masks, packed inside a manufacturing plant on Sunday night in a Las Vegas suburb, where President Trump brashly ignored a state directive limiting indoor gatherings to under 50 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Lettuce With Crunch
description: Bowery Farming’s Crispy Leaf lends texture to dishes that can use it, like salads and tacos.
content: Bowery Farming — a company that grows salad greens and herbs indoors in a pesticide-free vertical system — encourages you to rethink iceberg with its new crunchy Crispy Leaf, which adds nice texture to a salad and can be shredded for tacos. Despite what the company’s name and website suggest, the crops are not grown on the Bowery, but in buildings in Kearny, N.J., and outside Baltimore. The company, founded in New York City five years ago, picked the name because Bowery comes from an old Dutch word meaning farm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coralie Kraft
title: How Dev Hynes Went From Being in ‘We Are Who We Are’ to Scoring It
description: The musician and composer, widely known as Blood Orange, talked about helping create the mood of Luca Guadagnino’s new HBO series and about blending synthesizers with Schubert.
content: There is a moment at the beginning of Luca Guadagnino’s new HBO series, “We Are Who We Are,” when one of the main characters, Caitlin, stands poised atop a tower on an American army base in Italy, deciding whether to jump. Her friends have commandeered the training zip line attached to the tower, and, trussed like turkeys, they’ve already made the leap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: College Kids Are Freaking Out About Their Infected Campuses
description: Colleges and universities have become hot spots for coronavirus transmission. Bring on the gallows humor.
content: For Daniel Gardner, 19, a junior at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va., the dread and dejection set in before classes even started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Stirone
title: Missions to Venus: Highlights From History, and When We May Go Back
description: Much visited in an earlier era of space exploration, the planet has been overlooked in recent decades.
content: Carl Sagan once said that Venus is the planet in our solar system most like hell. So when are we going back?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Nick Corasaniti
title: Wisconsin’s Top Court Rules Against Reprinting of Ballots, Avoiding Election Chaos
description: Days before the start of mail voting, the state’s Supreme Court rejected an appeal by the Green Party’s candidate to reprint thousands of ballots so that his name could be added. The decision could help Joe Biden.
content: The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled on Monday that the Green Party’s presidential candidate will not appear on the state’s presidential ballot, a decision that prompted a sigh of relief among election officials who had worried that a wholesale reprinting of thousands of ballots could bring chaos to an already stressed electoral system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Facebook Is Failing in Global Disinformation Fight, Says Former Worker
description: The employee, who worked in a group dedicated to rooting out fake accounts, said executives ignored or were slow to react to her warnings.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — While Facebook has heralded improvements to its fight against disinformation in the United States, it has been slow to deal with fake accounts that have affected elections around the world, according to a post published by a former employee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: With Wit and Anger, Ayad Akhtar Addresses What It Means to Be American
description: “Homeland Elegies,” a novel that draws heavily on elements of memoir, is the story of a son and his immigrant father that has echoes of “The Great Gatsby.”
content: The presidency of Donald J. Trump, like a motorcycle that sets off two-thirds of the car alarms on a city street, has affected different writers in different ways. Some have gone nearly mad, for worse and sometimes better; some have tightened their noise-cancelling headphones and pretended the moral disruption isn’t there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Michael Schwirtz
title: Navalny, Awake and Alert, Plans to Return to Russia, German Official Says
description: Mr. Navalny talked with a German prosecutor about being poisoned. Word of his improvement came as France and Sweden confirmed that he had been sickened by Novichok, a Russian nerve agent.
content: BERLIN — Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who is recovering from being poisoned, has spoken to a German prosecutor about the attempt on his life and says he plans to return to Russia as soon as he has recovered, a senior German security official said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Trump Issues Expansive Order Aimed at Lowering Drug Prices
description: The order expands on a presidential promise by trying to reduce the prices Medicare pays for prescription drugs, but experts said it was unclear whether the White House could carry out the directive.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Sunday issued a far-reaching executive order aimed at lowering the cost of prescription drugs, but the pharmaceutical industry immediately denounced it and experts said it was unclear whether the White House could carry it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Makiko Inoue and Ben Dooley
title: Japan’s Next Prime Minister Emerges From Behind the Curtain
description: Yoshihide Suga’s years as a shadow power in Japanese politics left him a bit of a cipher.  Now he is emerging to take control of the world’s third-largest economy at a time of deep uncertainty.
content: TOKYO — Yoshihide Suga charted an unlikely course to the cusp of Japan’s premiership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Patricia Mazzei
title: What Trump and Biden are trying to do in Florida: look for votes in the margins.
description: Elections in Florida are won by running up margins in favorable terrain while losing more closely in hostile precincts. Joseph Biden visits the state on Tuesday for the first time since claiming the nomination.
content: LONGBOAT KEY, Fla. — Four years after President Trump won Florida by just over a percentage point, polls show that the state is, true to form, sitting on a knife’s edge — and looming again as a potential tipping point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Nancy Dine, Filmmaker and Muse of Artist Jim Dine, Dies at 83
description: In the 1960s, the Dines were an art world force in New York and London. Ms. Dine went on to make films about her husband, earning her an Academy Award nomination.
content: Nancy Dine, a filmmaker, muse and former wife of the artist Jim Dine, whose documentary about her husband earned her an Academy Award nomination, died on Sept. 6 at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Tom Brady Led the N.F.L.’s Week 1 Flops, but There Were Others
description: Some great football was played Sunday. This article is about the rest of it.
content: Forget celebrating the return of N.F.L. football by lauding Julio Jones’s hands, Christian McCaffrey’s legs and Lamar Jackson’s arm. Let’s celebrate it in a more ghoulish, and maybe pettier, way by looking at the players and teams who didn’t fare so well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Don’t Forget the Driver’ Is a Comedy for Our Moment
description: In a bittersweet BBC series, Toby Jones plays a beaten-down tour bus driver who, fitfully and reluctantly, tries to do the right thing.
content: Early in “Don’t Forget the Driver,” Pete Green, a tour-bus driver on England’s southern coast, returns from a day trip across the Channel and discovers he’s picked up a stowaway, a frightened young African woman. It’s a chance for him to do some small thing outside the sad orbit of his daily life, something decent and possibly heroic. And it’s absolutely terrifying — after a weak attempt to assist, Pete has to stagger away and sink to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The G.O.P. Plot to Sabotage 2021
description: Republicans are already acting as if there’s no next year.
content: Nobody knows for sure who will win in November. Joe Biden holds the advantage right now, but between the vagaries of the Electoral College and whatever October surprises the Trumpists cook up — you know they’re coming — who knows?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Under Trump, OSHA’s Covid-19 Response Is Failing Workers
description: Businesses have little to fear from the government’s workplace safety office.
content: Just $15,615. That’s how much a $52 billion meatpacking company was fined by the federal government for unsafe conditions that led to the deaths of eight workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Big Sean Ends Taylor Swift’s Reign on Album Chart
description: The rapper opened at No. 1 with his latest album, “Detroit 2.”
content: The Detroit rapper Big Sean has ended Taylor Swift’s six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden is creating a legal crisis response team, anticipating a major voting battle.
description: With two former solicitors general and hundreds of lawyers, the Biden campaign is bracing for an extended legal battle and hoping to maintain trust in the electoral process.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign is establishing a major new legal operation, bringing in two former solicitors general and hundreds of lawyers in what the campaign billed as the largest election protection program in presidential campaign history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Outrage Diet
description: What are we supposed to do with all this fury?
content: NASHVILLE — Nurses always smile at me when they check my blood pressure: Nothing to worry about there. But at a routine appointment recently, I was shocked to get a reading in the hypertension range. It was a temporary state, back to normal an hour later, but the whole episode was worrisome. I have no chronic illnesses. In the absence of any change in diet, weight or exercise, what could possibly account for a red flag like that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Patricia Mazzei
title: A Tight Trump-Biden Race in Florida: Here’s the State of Play
description: Elections in Florida are won by running up margins in favorable terrain while losing more closely in hostile precincts. Joseph Biden visits the state on Tuesday for the first time since claiming the nomination.
content: LONGBOAT KEY, Fla. — As Linda Kanner hoisted groceries into her Volvo outside the Publix in this affluent Gulf Coast enclave last week, she unleashed a stream of invective toward President Trump to explain why she would “vote for Mickey Mouse” before an incumbent whose conduct she finds appalling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump Defends Indoor Rally, but Aides Express Concern
description: “I’m on a stage, and it’s very far away,” Mr. Trump said of the gathering on Sunday. His own campaign aides privately called the move a game of political Russian roulette.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his campaign are defending his right to rally indoors, despite the private unease of aides who called it a game of political Russian roulette and growing concern that such gatherings could prolong the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Susan Sandler, a progressive megadonor, will give $200 million to racial justice groups.
description: Her efforts will support organizations trying to build political power in states that are undergoing rapid demographic change.
content: Susan Sandler, a liberal philanthropist, has announced a $200 million investment in racial justice organizations, targeting areas across the South and the Southwest that are experiencing rapid demographic transformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: esplanade
description: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
content: esplanade  \ ˈe-splə-ˌnäd , ˌe-splə-ˈnäd  \  noun
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: Listeners Found Beverly Glenn-Copeland. It Was Time.
description: In the 1970s and ’80s, his music went largely unheralded, but an audience finally caught up. A new career-spanning mixtape, “Transmissions,” traces the evolution of a life fully in bloom.
content: When Beverly Glenn-Copeland was 64, he entrusted Elizabeth Paddon, whom he would soon marry, with a sobering prediction: His records would finally be noticed after he died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: When You Love, and Loathe, Watching the N.F.L.
description: The return of professional football to a nation living on a raw and perilous edge, struggling to confront a lethal virus and trying to heal its deep racial wounds, offered fans a tense and unlikely paradox.
content: It was the return of a lost love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Daniel Boulud’s Next Restaurant Nods to a New York Classic
description: He’s naming a new Midtown place for the fabled Le Pavillon, but it will focus on seafood and forgo much of the original’s opulence.
content: The opening of a white-tablecloth restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, by the chef behind the very formal Daniel, might seem counterintuitive in the midst of a pandemic. But Daniel Boulud is embracing the timing, right down to the new restaurant’s name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Migrants Rescued by Tanker Arrive in Italy After Weekslong Standoff
description: The migrants were transferred from the tanker, the Maersk Etienne, to a humanitarian vessel before docking in Sicily after 40 days at sea.
content: Forty days after being rescued by a shipping tanker in the Mediterranean and then being prevented from coming ashore by the Maltese authorities, a group of 27 migrants was finally allowed to disembark in Italy over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: TikTok Owner’s Big Reason to Strike a U.S. Deal: China Is Slowing
description: ByteDance’s founder has long urged his employees to think beyond the world’s No. 2 economy, where growth is easing and competition is rising.
content: TikTok’s Chinese owner has fought tooth and nail to keep control over its wildly popular platform for dancing teens and young Los Angeles influencers. One big reason: The days of fast internet fortunes and meteoric digital growth in its home market may be coming to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: The Quest to Raffle Off Mexico’s Presidential Plane
description: The Mexican president has called the jet “an insult to the people,” but has failed to sell it or give it away. Some have called the spectacle a symbol of his leadership.
content: Even before he was elected, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador pointed to Mexico’s presidential plane as a symbol of all that was wrong with the political establishment in Mexico, where leaders lived lavishly amid a population in dire need.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Catholic Church and the Holocaust
description: Readers react to new revelations from the Vatican’s previously sealed archives.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: How New York City’s Police Unions Embraced Trump
description: The unions’ leadership is mostly white, suburban and Republican, setting it apart from an increasingly diverse police force and the city itself.
content: New York City’s largest police union had not endorsed a candidate for president in decades when its leader, Patrick J. Lynch, stepped to the lectern last month at President Trump’s golf club in New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How Flu Shots Can Help in the Fight Against Covid-19
description: Experts worry that the two diseases could overwhelm the health care system and create a new shortage of hospital beds and personal protective equipment.
content: While we anxiously await the development and approval of a safe and effective vaccine against Covid-19, there’s another health-sparing and lifesaving vaccine already available to nearly everyone over the age of 6 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What’s Your Relationship With Masks?
description: During this era of Covid-19, how often are you wearing a face mask?
content: Note to Teachers: Please read the entire featured article, which discusses a variety of health measures, to make sure it is appropriate for your students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tomás Pueyo
title: This Is Why We Couldn’t Control the Pandemic
description: Some countries slammed their doors. It worked — until they let outsiders back in.
content: Some countries slammed their doors. It worked — until they let outsiders back in.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Is Celebrity?
description: Our reporters have described the most — and least — important categories of American celebrity now, from the super-niche to the mega-famous. Now, it’s your turn to rank them.
content: Our reporters have described the most — and least — important categories of American celebrity now, from the super-niche to the mega-famous. Now, it’s your turn to rank them.

author: By David Marchese
title: John Cusack Never Understood His Cusackness
description: “Perhaps in a way, I had my own brand. I would have denied it, because that would be pretty unartistic.”
content: “Perhaps in a way, I had my own brand. I would have denied it, because that would be pretty unartistic.”

title: How to Get Better Air Quality
description: Breathing particulates is never good for your health, and in a disaster like the California wildfires, the risks are severe.

title: ‘Climate Change Is Real,’ Newsom Tells Trump at Briefing
description: During a meeting with local and state wildfire officials in California, Gov. Gavin Newsom politely disagreed with President Trump’s view on climate change.
content: During a meeting with local and state wildfire officials in California, Gov. Gavin Newsom politely disagreed with President Trump’s view on climate change.

description: Wildfires continued to burn over the weekend, leaving dire conditions for California and Oregon.

title: Sally’s Heavy Rains Hit Florida
description: Sally, which strengthened into a hurricane on Monday, drenched parts of Florida as it traveled toward Louisiana.
content: Sally, which strengthened into a hurricane on Monday, drenched parts of Florida as it traveled toward Louisiana.

author: By James Henry, Jackie James, Rey Jarrell and Amelie Zilber
title: Why You Should Care About TikTok
description: Forcing a sale of the app is a show of power, but it doesn’t really protect your privacy.
